monogr.title: A discourse of the great crueltie of a widowe towardes a yong gentleman, and by what meanes he requited the same. Set forth in English verse by Iohn God
monogr.author: God, John

div.head: The Prefac • to the Reader.
div.p:
MArk gentle reader, in this little tr • atis, both fonde and affectionate loue, the one proceeding from a loyall and gentle hear • e, rather decked with ve • tue, than follie, I say rath • r adorned, & beautified with Venus mild and gentle behauiour, than enuironned with the deadly and spitefull rage of uno: the other from a disdainefull and loths • me stomacke puffed vp with too muche superstition, vnder the coloure of mecke humilitie. with vainglorie, vnder the shadowe of constancie: with disdaine, vnder the pretence of perfect and sounde chastitie. They that haue passed the most part of their time in humaine follies, and haue rather foll • wed the vanities of fooles and insensuate louers in matters of loue (and the contemplation of heau • nlie things, or else of those that here on earth may giue some entrie for man to attaine glory and honour of his name) they I say shall serue mee
for witnesses to confirme the opinion of long time rooted in the fansies of men, which is, that the beautie & comely fauour of a woman is the most true and natural Adaman • that can be found, sith the same stone (for a certaine attractiue power and agreable qualitie therin enclosed) doth not better draw the iron, than a woman doth by a certaine hidden force, whiche rysing vnder the allurement of hir, draweth vnto it the heartes and affections of men, which hath made manie beleeue, that the same only essence was sent to vs belowe to serue bothe for mennes torment and ioy togither. But yet there is another thing of greater wonder, it is not to heare tell that Paris forsooke, Troy to go visite Helena in Grece, that Hercules had giuē ouer his mace to handle the distaffe at the commaundement of a woman, or that Salomon was s • tted in his wisdome to dallie with those which made him a voluntarie slaue. But that a woman of whom a man had receiued no fauour nor curtesie, had forgotten hir duetie to hir seruaunt, if it seeme not straunge, I knowe not what to call wonderfull or maruellous. If defence of speeche for loue, is not deemed suche whereby man is different from brute beastes: (for reason is altogither r • fuse • of • o • ers) and notwithstāding
our Fathers haue seene the example of that vertue no long time paste in the person of a Gentleman, verie wise and wel trained vp in other thinges, a case so straunge, as declaring the singular force of nature in that matter, wherein shee seemeth to haue giuen the preferment aboue all things in the earth. Examples hereof is the effemination of Hercules, the depriuation of Sampsons force, the losse of sense, and the Idelatrie of the famous and wise King Salomon, and the simplicitie of a warelesse & vncircumspecte Gentleman, of whome yee shall reade in the Historie following. Marke I say, (gentle Reader) howe fortune dealeth with them, which trusting in their force, despise (in respect of that whiche they doe them selues) the little portion whiche they iudged to bee in others. If the vaineglorie and arrogant presumption of a chastitie impregnable, had not deceiued the Gentlewomanne following in this Treatise, if the sugred hunger of golde had not blinded hir, it coulde not haue bin knowne wherein hir inconstancie consisted, not in the minion delites and alluring toyes of a passionate Louer, but in the couetous desire of filling hir purse, and hypocriticall glorye of praise a

menne: Notwithstanding, you shall see the gaine whiche shee made; to serue hir turne nothing at all, but to the perpetuall reproche of hir name, and raysed a slaunder, suche as ill speakers and enimies of womenkinde do burden that sex withall. But the fault of one whiche by hir owne presumption disceiued hir selfe, ought not to obscure the glorie of so manye vertuous, faire, and honest dames, who by their chastitie, liberalitie and curtesie, bee able too deface the blot of follie, couetousnesse, and crueltie of this Gentlewoman heere, and of all other that doe resemble hir: notwithstanding in the ende reconciling hir selfe, and abhorring the foolishe fantasie of hir former life, with an ordinarie greefe of him whiche serued hir for a spurre too hir conscience, and continually forced hir too thinke, that the force of a man is lesse than nothing where God work • th not by his grace, who failing in vs, our wo • kes can sauor but of the stenche and corruption of our nature, wherein it tumbleth and tosseth as the sow in the puddles of dirt and mire. This breefe discourse giueth lessons vnto Louers to auoide the imm • derate pangues of loue, it doth 〈◊〉 the indiscretion of promised penaunce,
it warneth to beware all 〈…〉 heastes, least the penalties of couetous •••• and vaineglory be incurred, whiche shall manifest it selfe, if you marke the sense thereof in Reading. And that the same might the more delighte thee, I haue turned it into simple verse, according as my capacitie woulde serue, but notwithstanding take it in worth, which I know to be full of errors, and not so eloquent as you require, nor so delectable as I wold desire. Thus greeting thee, I bid thee farewell.
